stem: The triage nurse is assessing victims from an apartment building fire. Based on the documentation in the Trauma Flowsheet, match each victim with the most appropriate triage category.

tabs.title: Incident Overview
tabs.content:
02:00: High-rise apartment fire reported. Multiple entrapped victims. 
02:30: Triage area established. Smoke is heavy in the staging area. 
03:00: Victims arriving with varying degrees of thermal and inhalation injuries.

tabs.title: Trauma Flowsheet
tabs.content:
VictimRR / Breath SoundsPerfusion / HRInjury/Meds Status
Victim ARR 32; Stridor notedHR 132; CR 1.8sSinged nasal hairs; Alert
Victim BRR 24; Clear bilaterallyHR 118; CR 2.2s60% Full-thickness burns; Unresponsive
Victim CRR 22; ClearHR 98; CR 1.5s15% Partial-thickness burns to arms/legs
Victim DRR 18; ClearHR 84; CR 1.2sMinor lacerations; Walking

tabs.title: Airway Assessment
tabs.content:
Victim A: Carbonaceous sputum observed. 
Victim B: No signs of life after airway adjustment.

rows.text: Victim A: RR 32, Stridor, singed nasal hairs

rationale.correct: Victim A is **Red** because their RR is > 30 and they have stridor (Inhalation injury threat). Victim B is **Black** because they are unresponsive and non-breathing (Expectant). Victim C is **Yellow** because they have significant burns (15%) but pass RPM (RR < 30, CR < 2s, Alert). Victim D is **Green** because they are ambulatory.
clinicalPearls: Stridor and singed nasal hairs is a medical emergency (Airway closure).
In a disaster, a victim who is non-breathing receives one airway check. If no breath, they are Black.

questionTrap.trap: Coding Victim B as Red because 60% burns are severe.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In triage, 'Unresponsive and Non-breathing' always takes precedence as a Black tag regardless of the injury severity.

mnemonic.title: START RPM
mnemonic.expansion: R: Respirations (>30). P: Perfusion (CR >2). M: Mental Status (Cannot do).
